Sustains knee injury while playing rugby in high school.

International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) introduces rule 144.2, which prohibits: (e) Use of any technical device that incorporates springs, wheels or any other element that provides the user with an advantage over another athlete not using such a device.
In Rome, finishes second in the 400m 'B' race against able-bodied athletes.
The race is an IAAF test to observe and determine if rule 144.2 (e) is being broken.
The results are inconclusive.

Completes a series of tests in Cologne, Germany, to evaluate the metabolic differences in amputees and non-amputees and whether or not those differences caused by use of the Flex-Foot Cheetah prosthetics violate rule 144.2(e).
The report claims that the prosthetics give Pistorius an advantage over able-bodied competitors, which Pistorius strongly rejects.

Pistorius is banned from competing in all IAAF-sanctioned events, "...running with these prostheses requires a less-important vertical movement associated with a lesser mechanical effort to raise the body, and the energy loss resulting from the use of these prostheses is significantly lower than that resulting from a human ankle joint at a maximal sprint speed.
" The ruling is based on the evaluation done in Germany in November 2007.
An appeal to the ban is filed with the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) by Pistorius through the law firm of Dewey & LeBoeuf.
The CAS reverses the January IAAF ban on Pistorius and the Cheetahs, making him eligible to compete in the Beijing Olympics.
Sustains major head and facial injuries in a boat accident on the Vaal River near Johannesburg.
Becomes the first double-amputee runner to compete in the Olympics, coming in eighth place in the 400m semifinal.
Pistorius also later runs the anchor leg of the 4x400m relay final where the South African team comes in eighth place.
Pistorius's girlfriend, South African model Reeva Steenkamp, is found shot to death at Oscar Pretorius's Pretoria, South Africa, home.
Pistorius is arrested.
Pistorius is officially charged with premeditated murder in the death of Steenkamp.
Nike follows eyewear maker Oakley in also suspending their endorsement deal with Pistorius.
Leaves jail after posting a cash bond of 100,000 rand (about $11,200).
Another 900,000 rand (about $100,800) is due by March 1.
The conditions of Pistorius's bail are that he must avoid his home where the shooting occurred, relinquish his passport and abstain from drinking alcohol.
Judge Bert Bam lifts the travel ban on Pistorius, saying he sees no reason Pistorius should not be allowed to travel for competition.
The ban on drinking alcohol and avoiding his home where the shooting occurred  is also lifted.
The murder trial begins
The judge rules that Pistorius must undergo mental health examinations over the next month.
A psychiatric assessment finds that Pistorius was not mentally incapacitated when he shot Steenkamp to death.
Is found guilty of culpable homicide, the South African term for unintentionally -- but unlawfully -- killing a person.
Receives a five-year sentence
South Africa's Department of Correctional Services tells CNN that a parole board is set to recommend that Pistorius be released from prison and transferred to house arrest in August.
A parole review board opts to "set aside the decision"
In a statement, the parole board says it has approved Pistorius' placement under house arrest and correctional supervision for four years.
Is released from prison and placed under house arrest,
Oscar Pistorius' conviction for "culpable homicide" is changed to murder.
Judge Eric Leach overturns the previous conviction, saying the original ruling was flawed.
Is granted bail.
A South African judge sentences Pistorius to six years in prison for Steenkamp's murder.
Barring an appeal, this will be the final sentencing.
State prosecutors ask to appeal the sentencing, telling the Supreme Court of Appeal that a six-year prison term is too lenient.
The Supreme Court of Appeal increases Pistorius' sentence to 13 years and five months for the murder of Steenkamp.
